conclusion: The problem involves understanding the behavior of an ideal gas as it transitions through different states on a pressure-volume (p-V) diagram.
We'll use the Ideal Gas Law and some thermodynamic principles to find the temperature at state C.

State A has a pressure \( p_A = 3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \), volume \( V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \), and temperature \( T_A = 27^\circ \text{C} = 300 \text{ K} \) (converting Celsius to Kelvin).
State B has a pressure \( p_B = 1 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \) and volume \( V_B = 1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \).
State C has a pressure \( p_C = 1 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \) and volume \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \).

premise: From state A to state B, the volume remains constant (\( V_A = V_B \)), which indicates an isochoric (constant volume) process.

conclusion: Substituting the values: \(\frac{3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}}{300 \text{ K}} = \frac{1 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}}{T_B}\)

premise: Substituting the values: \(\frac{3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}}{300 \text{ K}} = \frac{1 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}}{T_B}\)
conclusion: Solving for \( T_B \): \(T_B = \frac{(1 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}) \times 300 \text{ K}}{3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}} = 100 \text{ K}\)

premise: From state B to state C, the pressure remains constant (\( p_B = p_C \)), which indicates an isobaric (constant pressure) process.
conclusion: Using the Ideal Gas Law again: \(\frac{V_B}{T_B} = \frac{V_C}{T_C}\)
Substituting the values: \(\frac{1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3}{100 \text{ K}} = \frac{3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3}{T_C}\)

premise: Substituting the values: \(\frac{1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3}{100 \text{ K}} = \frac{3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3}{T_C}\)
